head.title: Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. - Page #9

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #9 of 32 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Umfreville, Edward. Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0030

div.p: the Lake opens wide, a remarkable round island of high land appearing in the front of the Strait – then rod the point to the So point of an island NW1½m. havg many islands on our right – NNW1m. to a point on the main – then No 2m. across a Bay, passing very near an island on our Right – then rod the point, & along a steep rocky Shore NW4m. to the Wt end of an isld very high & shaped like a Barn. Here we met with a Tent of Inds one of whom we intended to engage as a Pilot, but they were unacquainted with the road. We made them a small present of Tobacco powder & Shot & departed. Opposite to this point NWbN3m. at the bottom of a Bay lays the beginning of the River we have to enter: 3 pointed mountains lay on the left near its entrance. 1st Course in the River NbW½m. S.C. & abt 60yds wide, then NW¼m. to the Portage le petit Jour, 280yds over & good road, at the bottom of this rapid plenty of fish may be taken – then NWbN2½m. strong Currt small rapid & stones above water & shoaly in places, the men debark'd & led ye Canoe up the middle of it, at the end of this Co the river opens wide forming a small Lake then NW1m. to a point. The Inds we left follow'd us with their families & Baggage.

June 26 Sunday Saturday. The Inds here offer'd a few Skins to Trade, & they would have been displeas'd had we denied it. These with a few got from the Guide amounts to 8 Otters, 1 Peccant, 2 Beaver, 2 cub Beaver, 3 martins & 2 mink. Nothing was done this day, but making a net with smaller meshes. The distress we are in for a Guide is very great. This fellow possesses all the duplicity of the devil himself. One day he knows our way better than any Indian in the Country, the next day he knows nothing abt it, at one time he is ready to do us any Service, & soon after will Threaten our lives but our Situation is such, we must accept of him or give up the Journey[.]

27 Sunday. The Guide said this morng he would go with us no farther, so that we we resolv'd to wait here 'till the French people pass by, especially as the men have no aOccassion to eat much of their Corn, fish being tolerably plenty. Finding we were likely to remain here this day[,] I went in an Indian canoe across the lake to the River we have to enter. I went as far as the 2d Carrying place & then return'd, but was much concern'd to find the Inds all drunk, notwithstanding it had been my ust utmost care to keep them sober, especially while our villain of a Guide is with them. It seems they came & took the liquor forcibly, tho' they were but 3 of them & 6 of our People. St Germaine says none of the men would help him except Jean Roy, they afterwds recover'd the liquor, but not 'till the Inds had taken out enough to make them all drunk men & women. I expected much Trouble in consequence of the above, & accordingly we had our hands full. Our old troublesome fellow was so outrageous, we could hardly keep him from breaking the Canoe, & doing every mischief. He was particularly violent agt me, for detecting him in his last villiany. The other Inds were very peaceable & help'd us to cool this Firebrand, in short we know not what to do with him, he follows us every where, destroys our provisions & keeps us under continual apprehensions.

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
